figure_1.title: Figure 1.
figure_1.caption: Eye-mounting goggles holding an enucleated (pig) eye. (a) Top-down view. (b) Side view. (c) Components used in the construction of the eye-mounting goggles. BTU ball transfer unit.

figure_2.title: Figure 2.
figure_2.caption: Achieving rotational stiffness. (a) A simple pendulum model is used to illustrate the equivalent model for (b) the moment about the center of the bowl due to gravity, where the force of gravity acting at the center of mass (CoM) of the bowl creates a moment about the center of rotation (CoR). (c) Ranges of restoring torques corresponding to the measurements provided by Rosenbaum and Myer18, as well as the torques resulting from the pendulum model at two nominal stiffnesses.

figure_3.title: Figure 3.
figure_3.caption: Determining placement of ball transfer units (BTUs). (a) Depiction of maximal bowl rotation, at which the edge of the bowl loses contact with a BTU. (b) BTU placement that results in the lowest point of the bowl being at the same height as the lowest point on each BTU, with the BTUs placed normal to the bowl’s surface. For clarity, only one BTU is shown. (c) Geometric parameters of the BTUs.

figure_4.title: Figure 4.
figure_4.caption: Assembled ball-transfer-unit (BTU) holder and bowl. (a) Top view of the BTU holder on swim goggles, with BTUs inserted. A gap in the BTU holder leaves space for the nose and the bridge of the goggles. (b) Bowl without a brim, rotated by , which is the angle at which it loses contact with a BTU. (c) Bowl with a brim, rotated by . The brim prevents the bowl from losing contact with the BTUs.

figure_5.title: Figure 5.
figure_5.caption: The surgeons’ responses to our questionnaire.

figure_6.title: Figure 6.
figure_6.caption: Model used to determine maximum-allowable head rotation. (a) The configuration corresponding to the smallest head rotation angle, , at which the bowl will fall off the ball transfer units (BTUs). The center of mass (CoM) of the bowl is located directly above the line connecting the points at which the two lower BTUs contact the bowl. (b) Reference frames used to calculate the rotation of the wearer’s head, , and the rotation of the bowl, , at which the bowl will fall off of the BTUs. Each frame shares the same color as the object(s) to which it is rigidly connected.

figure_7.title: Figure 7.
figure_7.caption: The height of the mounted eye, , above the head’s instantaneous center of rotation (ICoR), will be greater than the height of the volunteer’s eye, , which will result in a discrepancy between the movement of the two eyes.

claims.sentence: In this paper, we propose a device that mounts an artificial or enucleated eye to a set of standard swim goggles, which can be worn by a human volunteer during practice with, and evaluation of, eye-surgery robots (Fig. 1).

Lack of eye motion might make it more difficult to translate skills obtained during training to performance in clinical practice.Results
Design concept
Our fabricated eye-mounting goggles, along with the individual components, are shown in Fig. 1.

Figure 2 shows how the quasistatic dynamics of the bowl can be approximated as a simple pendulum model, where the center of rotation (CoR) is coincident with the center of the bounding sphere of the bowl.
The mass m (units kg) of the bowl can be modeled as a point mass at the location of the center of mass (CoM), which is located at a distance  (units m) from the CoR (Fig. 2b).

This approximates the torque–rotation relationship of a linear torsional spring with a spring constant K (units N m/rad), where


2

Figure 2.
This comparison is illustrated in Fig. 2c.
The three points of contact between the BTUs and the bowl form an equilateral triangle, with each point a distance a from the center of the triangle (Fig. 3a,b).
Although the BTU concept is somewhat robust to misalignment, we choose the nominal design to place the BTUs normal to the surface of the spherical bowl (Fig. 3b).

For a spherical bowl of outer radius R, we will be able to rotate the bowl by an angle


4

before the bowl loses contact with one of the BTUs, as depicted in Fig. 3a.

Thus, for some desired maximum rotation angle, , we should select


5

Figure 3.
This configuration is shown in Fig. 3b, with only one BTU shown for clarity.

From the geometry of the BTU (Fig. 3c), we find that


7

Referencing Fig. 3b, the point on the semicircle where the BTU contacts the bowl is.
The prototype BTU holder, which places the BTUs in the poses described above, is shown in Fig. 4a.
Without the brim, the bowl may lose contact with a BTU if it is rotated by more than  (Fig. 4b).
We designed the brim such that when the bowl is rotated to its maximum rotation angle, , the profile of the brim matches that of the BTU and prevents the bowl from rotating farther (Fig. 4c).
The responses from the surgeons were unanimously positive (Fig. 5), so we determined there was no need for further design iteration.
Figure 6a shows the configuration that corresponds to the smallest value of  at which the bowl will fall off.
To find when the bowl will fall off the BTUs, as a function of both  and the rotation of the bowl, , we define coordinate frames that are shown in Fig. 6b.

We use kinematics equations to derive the equation describing the configuration at which the bowl falls off of the BTUs as a function of  and :


9

Figure 6.
We can quantify the effect of the offset using a simple model for the motion of the volunteer’s head (Fig. 7).

Both STL files are available as supplementary material.Maximum rotation of the volunteer’s head
We use the product of exponentials convention for forward kinematics as described by Murray et al.31 to derive , which is the homogeneous transformation matrix describing the pose of Frame 2 relative to Frame 0 as a function of the angle of the head, , and the angle of the bowl, :


16

where  corresponds to the reference configuration shown in Fig. 6b.

For a rotation of angle  about a unit vector ,


17

where , ,  is a vector from the origin of Coordinate Frame 0 to a point on the  axis,  and  are expressed in Frame 0, and  is a skew–symmetric matrix containing the components of  as


18

For our device, we have


19

and

The configuration shown in Fig. 6a, where the bowl falls off the BTUs, occurs when  and the x-component of  is equal to zero.

In this paper, we propose a device that mounts an artificial or enucleated eye to a set of standard swim goggles, which can be worn by a human volunteer during practice with, and evaluation of, eye-surgery robots (Fig. 1).

Lack of eye motion might make it more difficult to translate skills obtained during training to performance in clinical practice.Results
Design concept
Our fabricated eye-mounting goggles, along with the individual components, are shown in Fig. 1.

Figure 2 shows how the quasistatic dynamics of the bowl can be approximated as a simple pendulum model, where the center of rotation (CoR) is coincident with the center of the bounding sphere of the bowl.
The mass m (units kg) of the bowl can be modeled as a point mass at the location of the center of mass (CoM), which is located at a distance  (units m) from the CoR (Fig. 2b).

This approximates the torque–rotation relationship of a linear torsional spring with a spring constant K (units N m/rad), where


2

Figure 2.
This comparison is illustrated in Fig. 2c.
The three points of contact between the BTUs and the bowl form an equilateral triangle, with each point a distance a from the center of the triangle (Fig. 3a,b).
Although the BTU concept is somewhat robust to misalignment, we choose the nominal design to place the BTUs normal to the surface of the spherical bowl (Fig. 3b).

For a spherical bowl of outer radius R, we will be able to rotate the bowl by an angle


4

before the bowl loses contact with one of the BTUs, as depicted in Fig. 3a.

Thus, for some desired maximum rotation angle, , we should select


5

Figure 3.
This configuration is shown in Fig. 3b, with only one BTU shown for clarity.

From the geometry of the BTU (Fig. 3c), we find that


7

Referencing Fig. 3b, the point on the semicircle where the BTU contacts the bowl is.
The prototype BTU holder, which places the BTUs in the poses described above, is shown in Fig. 4a.
Without the brim, the bowl may lose contact with a BTU if it is rotated by more than  (Fig. 4b).
We designed the brim such that when the bowl is rotated to its maximum rotation angle, , the profile of the brim matches that of the BTU and prevents the bowl from rotating farther (Fig. 4c).
The responses from the surgeons were unanimously positive (Fig. 5), so we determined there was no need for further design iteration.
Figure 6a shows the configuration that corresponds to the smallest value of  at which the bowl will fall off.
To find when the bowl will fall off the BTUs, as a function of both  and the rotation of the bowl, , we define coordinate frames that are shown in Fig. 6b.

We use kinematics equations to derive the equation describing the configuration at which the bowl falls off of the BTUs as a function of  and :


9

Figure 6.
We can quantify the effect of the offset using a simple model for the motion of the volunteer’s head (Fig. 7).

Both STL files are available as supplementary material.Maximum rotation of the volunteer’s head
We use the product of exponentials convention for forward kinematics as described by Murray et al.31 to derive , which is the homogeneous transformation matrix describing the pose of Frame 2 relative to Frame 0 as a function of the angle of the head, , and the angle of the bowl, :

The configuration shown in Fig. 6a, where the bowl falls off the BTUs, occurs when  and the x-component of  is equal to zero.

In this paper, we propose a device that mounts an artificial or enucleated eye to a set of standard swim goggles, which can be worn by a human volunteer during practice with, and evaluation of, eye-surgery robots (Fig. 1).

In this paper, we propose a device that mounts an artificial or enucleated eye to a set of standard swim goggles, which can be worn by a human volunteer during practice with, and evaluation of, eye-surgery robots (Fig. 1).

Results
Design concept
Our fabricated eye-mounting goggles, along with the individual components, are shown in Fig. 1.

Figure 2 shows how the quasistatic dynamics of the bowl can be approximated as a simple pendulum model, where the center of rotation (CoR) is coincident with the center of the bounding sphere of the bowl.
The mass m (units kg) of the bowl can be modeled as a point mass at the location of the center of mass (CoM), which is located at a distance  (units m) from the CoR (Fig. 2b).

This approximates the torque–rotation relationship of a linear torsional spring with a spring constant K (units N m/rad), where

The three points of contact between the BTUs and the bowl form an equilateral triangle, with each point a distance a from the center of the triangle (Fig. 3a,b).
Although the BTU concept is somewhat robust to misalignment, we choose the nominal design to place the BTUs normal to the surface of the spherical bowl (Fig. 3b).

For a spherical bowl of outer radius R, we will be able to rotate the bowl by an angle

The prototype BTU holder, which places the BTUs in the poses described above, is shown in Fig. 4a.
Without the brim, the bowl may lose contact with a BTU if it is rotated by more than  (Fig. 4b).
We designed the brim such that when the bowl is rotated to its maximum rotation angle, , the profile of the brim matches that of the BTU and prevents the bowl from rotating farther (Fig. 4c).
The responses from the surgeons were unanimously positive (Fig. 5), so we determined there was no need for further design iteration.
